ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned much about corruption in antiquity and modernity.
I learned how to think about political concepts whose definitions have evolved over time, how to trace this evolution, and the consequences of the evolution.
Analyzing fundamentals of antiquity as corruption becomes a framework and understanding relevant in structures today.

I really enjoyed how the course worked chronologically to help students connect ideas from ancient societies to modern societal discussions. This course offered such a broad overview and helped students find topics within 'corruption' that interested them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great course. Professor Stephens has been my favorite professor thus far. Discussions were always very engaging and relevant to the material as well as current day topics.

This is a fantastic course, but I would have appreciated more focus on Ancient Rome and less focus on modern corruption (as opposed to the current 50-50 split between ancient and modern). I was somewhat surprised (maybe just based on the name of the course) by how much we discussed modern corruption. At times, it definitely felt more like a political science course than a history course.

Strengths: Loved loved loved the prof. What a chill yet so informational professor who excites you to participate and think broadly about concepts in class. He was super understanding as this semester was rough as it was. Weaknesses: none -- just engage in the class and you will get so much out of it!

The course was small and intimate. The instructors helped lead the discussions and the students from various backgrounds were able to offer novel connections and points that facilitated the discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would absolutely recommend this course.  Professor Stephens was great, and I really enjoyed the discussions every week.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students, especially political science majors and students interested in Ancient Rome. Professor Stephens is one of the best professors I have had at Yale!

Absolutely! I initially took this class for the writing credit, but I came away with much more. I was able to explore the various facets of corruption in antiquity and modernity with a non-history background. I had fun el oh el

It's listed under the history department but it is much more than that! Take the course if you would be interested in taking some time to make connections between practices in ancient societies and modern.
